9/To argue fruitfully with a Gish Galloper, you must focus on gestalt arguments.   You must play his game, because he just doesn't know how to play yours.

The key thing, I think, is that it's very hard to make new institutions to cope with new technological and economic realities. It's not something that 1, 100, or even 10,000 people can just intentionally do in 10 years. It takes more people, and longer.

One of the most consistent human biases is the illusion of control. We want to think that our culture, our ideas, and our will determine the shape of society. But in reality, I think we mostly just adapt to technological change.

...So yes, social change is hard, and yes, it's harder for people without the smarts, money, openness, work ethic, etc. to cope with it, and yes, people with less of these need institutions more, but no, the old stuff won't work, and yes, we're working on new stuff.  How's that?

...And I think that people who imagine that the old institutions of local churches etc. can simply resume their previous function, and we can force society back to the way it was pre-cars and -internet, are engaging in counterproductive fantasy...

...And contrary to what this guy thinks, it's urban cosmopolitan liberal types who have been working the hardest on crafting these new institutions, which can be seen in Robert Putnam's research for example...

Now *that* would be apples-to-oranges.  We want to compare investments. Society has financial capital that we can invest in a menu of projects. We invested $4.5B in Uber and $306M in Arpa-E last year. So we should ask ourselves if that allocation makes sense.

Moryl, if I was trying to make an apples-to-oranges comparison to say Uber is worthless, I'd have used Uber's total cost rather than its financial loss. :-)  $4.5B = the net amount Uber funded itself with investors' money. Hence, it's an apples-to-apples comparison.

The people who run Twitter seem to still have this core, bedrock belief that if everyone would just sit down and talk things out, they'd end up agreeing more than before.   That argument is the (bumpy) path to social harmony.

An algorithmic system designed to foment disagreement, in the name of breaking up "echo chambers", will tend to amplify the voices of the most disagreeable people in the world.  And that's exactly what this platform does.

For example, suppose a whole bunch of people agree that Nazis are bad.  Well, if your algorithm says "Always prevent echo chambers", then the algorithm will find someone to say "Well, actually, Nazis are OK".  And what kind of people say "Well actually, Nazis are OK"?

18/When it settles down to that long-run "equilibrium", its price may be greater than now, or less than now.  So, sorry, I can't tell you whether to buy or sell Bitcoin.

17/Now, is Bitcoin a bubble, or not?  Answer: I don't know. I believe in the final "equilibrium" (whatever that means), it WILL have an ongoing use as a means of purchasing illegal goods, evading capital controls, and evading financial regulations.

16/But just because something is a bubble doesn't mean it can't make you lots of money!   It just means that it's a zero-sum game - your gain comes entirely from someone else's loss, since no capital is being allocated to real, productive assets.

14/In other words, you are betting that other people will voluntarily redistribute their real wealth into your hands.   You are betting that human nature and the workings of financial markets will effect a redistribution from other investors to you.

13/You are investing in the likelihood that other people after you will buy more Bitcoin, increasing demand and raising its price, thus allowing you to sell your Bitcoin for more fiat money, with which to buy things like hamburgers.

11/I suspect that if a handful of people managed to lay claim to most of the world's physical wealth by nudging the world into a new money-coordination equilibrium, the Powers That Be would deploy military force of some sort.

10/Now, personally, I feel like in this scenario, the Powers That Be would not allow a handful of coders, online asset hucksters, and lucky speculators to suddenly appropriate all the real material wealth in the world - the houses, the hamburgers, the Teslas, the robot strippers.
9/Obviously, Bitcoin boosters are hoping for this to happen.   Everyone would like to just take Mark Zuckerberg's wealth and put it in their own pocket, would they not?

8/The world would have the same amount of stuff, but now that stuff would be owned (or easily ownable) mainly by early Bitcoin holders. Everyone else - Mark Zuckerberg, Vladimir Putin, the Sultan of Brunei - would become beggars (unless they were early BTC holders).

7/The "Bitcoin conquers fiat money" scenario would entail a radical redistribution of all the claims to real value that exist on this planet. The fiat-rich would become impoverished, while early Bitcoin holders became the new super-rich.

5/Money is a coordination game; it has value because we all agree to use the same type of money.   So if the world switches from fiat currencies to Bitcoin, as many Bitcoin boosters expect, people who held Bitcoin early will be much wealthier than before.

3/Yes yes, it can create real value to sell drugs (if addiction harm doesn't outweigh the utility of drugs), to evade capital controls, and to do unregulated finance (if financial regulation is over-burdensome).  Let's put that aside for the moment.

2/Though some blockchain apps may create real value, Bitcoin does not create (much) real value. In fact, because it sucks electricity, it probably destroys value. Traditional payment methods are much cheaper and easier.

Now, working immigrants are not rich retirees. But you can apply the same principle. Working immigrants supply labor, but they also demand goods and services produced by labor. So both curves shift, not just one.

Just to show this with an easy thought experiment, imagine a bunch of rich retirees moved here and spent down their savings. That would shift ONLY labor demand, and not labor supply, unambiguously boosting wages for native-born workers.
Matt is correct. The simple model is OK, but you should be using it differently - shifting both curves instead of just shifting one.

Yes, the key is that immigration causes labor demand, as well as labor supply, to shift to the right.   That's going to shrink that rectangle a lot, and could even make the rectangle positive for native-born workers rather than negative.

Oh, Eric, it's also helpful to think of immigration kind of like a baby boom. New young people increase labor supply, but they also increase labor demand! Otherwise we could just raise wages by restricting fertility... :-)
